document_metadata.name: Chaperoning α7 neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptors

links.evidence: α7 AChRs can act at the presynaptic, postsynaptic or perisynaptic levels to facilitate the liberation of neurotransmitters, mediate synaptic transmission, or modulate the connections of different neurons by activating diverse second messenger routes [1,19,23–31].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: α7 AChRs can act at the presynaptic, postsynaptic or perisynaptic levels to facilitate the liberation of neurotransmitters, mediate synaptic transmission, or modulate the connections of different neurons by activating diverse second messenger routes [1,19,23–31].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: α7 AChRs can act at the presynaptic, postsynaptic or perisynaptic levels to facilitate the liberation of neurotransmitters, mediate synaptic transmission, or modulate the connections of different neurons by activating diverse second messenger routes [1,19,23–31].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: AChRs have been linked to many neurodegenerative disorders [13,47–60].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: BDNF can also inﬂuence the level of α7 AChRs subunits (Fig. 4) in the hippocampus and other brain regions [160,164,165].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Additionally, SNARE-dependent trafﬁcking was required for α7 AChRs to be capable of activating the transcription factor cAMP response element-binding protein and attendant gene ex- pression when challenged.

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Reduction of α7 AChRs in the CNS is linked with Alzheimer dis- ease, which has been shown to lead to neuronal loss [53,188–190].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Decreased expression of α7 AChR has also been associated with schizophrenia [51,195–197].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Since α7 AChRs are highly permeable to calcium [198] and increased calcium permeability is required for neuronal migration [199], neurons with less α7 AChRs would fail to migrate to their correct destinations [200] and be activated by acetylcholine.

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: During acute in- ﬂammatory processes α7 AChRs attenuate renal failure induced by ische- mia/reperfusion by inhibiting pro-inﬂammatory cytokine expression, and subsequently decreasing cell apoptosis [180,201].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: During acute in- ﬂammatory processes α7 AChRs attenuate renal failure induced by ische- mia/reperfusion by inhibiting pro-inﬂammatory cytokine expression, and subsequently decreasing cell apoptosis [180,201].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: During acute in- ﬂammatory processes α7 AChRs attenuate renal failure induced by ische- mia/reperfusion by inhibiting pro-inﬂammatory cytokine expression, and subsequently decreasing cell apoptosis [180,201].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: AChRs have been linked to many neurodegenerative disorders [13,47–60].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Additionally, the pro- lyl isomerase enzyme cyclophilin has been shown to be necessary for efﬁcient folding of the α7 subunit in Xenopus oocytes [85–88].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: There is evidence that AChR folding, assembly and trafﬁcking are inﬂuenced by several chaperone proteins, such as the 14-3-3 protein [92,93], BiP [94–96] or calnexin [97–99].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: There is evidence that AChR folding, assembly and trafﬁcking are inﬂuenced by several chaperone proteins, such as the 14-3-3 protein [92,93], BiP [94–96] or calnexin [97–99].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: There is evidence that AChR folding, assembly and trafﬁcking are inﬂuenced by several chaperone proteins, such as the 14-3-3 protein [92,93], BiP [94–96] or calnexin [97–99].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Rapsyn is essential for AChR clustering in muscle [100] and has also been detected in non-muscle cells, including neurons of the ciliary ganglia [101,102], ﬁbroblasts [103], myocardial cells, and Leydig cells [104].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: More re- cently, the transmembrane protein resistant to inhibitors of cholines- terase (RIC-3), originally identiﬁed in Caenorhabditis elegans, has been classed as a much more selective chaperone of the AChR [71,107–112].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Co-expression with RIC-3 was shown to be required for AChR ac- tivity in C. elegans body muscles and for enhanced AChR activity in Xenopus oocytes [110,112].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Interestingly, levels of RIC-3 mRNA are elevat- ed in postmortem brains of individuals with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia [181], and a link has been suggested between deﬁ- cient RIC-3 mediated chaperoning of an AChR subunit and individ- uals with bipolar disorder and psychotic symptoms [181].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: In C. elegans, RIC-3 is necessary for synaptic transmission mediated by neuronal AChRs but not by other LGICs [71,77,109].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: In contrast, RIC-3 caused a marked inhibition of functional responses with hetero- meric α3β4 and α4β2 AChRs in Xenopus oocytes [109].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: In contrast, RIC-3 caused a marked inhibition of functional responses with hetero- meric α3β4 and α4β2 AChRs in Xenopus oocytes [109].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Osman et al. [122] ﬁnd that RIC-3 expression increases the total amount of α9 AChR in CL4 cells, supporting the view that RIC-3 regulates AChR trafﬁcking by increasing the number of mature or correctly folded receptor subunits reaching the cell surface.

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: It is noteworthy that RIC-3 has been shown to increase α7 AChR heterologous expression both in X. laevis oocytes and in HEK-293, CHO and SHE-P1 mammalian cell lines [66,71,77,107–112,119,125].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Interestingly, levels of RIC-3 mRNA are elevat- ed in postmortem brains of individuals with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia [181], and a link has been suggested between deﬁ- cient RIC-3 mediated chaperoning of an AChR subunit and individ- uals with bipolar disorder and psychotic symptoms [181].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Interestingly, levels of RIC-3 mRNA are elevat- ed in postmortem brains of individuals with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia [181], and a link has been suggested between deﬁ- cient RIC-3 mediated chaperoning of an AChR subunit and individ- uals with bipolar disorder and psychotic symptoms [181].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Regulation of receptor subunits by the proteasome, the large pro- tein complex that proteolytically degrades unneeded proteins, has also been demonstrated [113,114].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Furthermore, the proteasome in- directly regulates synaptic transmission mediated by AChRs via regu- lation of RIC-3 [113].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Furthermore, the proteasome in- directly regulates synaptic transmission mediated by AChRs via regu- lation of RIC-3 [113].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: One of the salient events at early stages of this disease (usually pre- clinical) is the impairment in hippocampus-based episodic memory which can be improved by enhancement of cholinergic transmission [191].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Co- expression of RIC-3 with the 5-HT 3 receptor in X. laevis oocytes totally abolishes 5-HT 3 surface expression [108,109].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Reduced expression of the lat- ter protein has been shown to be detrimental to AChR function in C. elegans [113] (See Fig. 2).

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Although the mechanisms that regulate phosphorylation of AChRs are still essen- tially unknown, protein tyrosine phosphorylation by the SFKs has been shown to affect peripheral AChRs in various ways, depending on the tis- sue, subunit type and functional role of the receptors involved.

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: In Torpedo electric organ, phosphorylation of AChRs by SFKs causes subtle changes in desensitization kinetics but not in I max , the maximal current ﬂowing through the receptor channel [141–143].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: In Torpedo electric organ, phosphorylation of AChRs by SFKs causes subtle changes in desensitization kinetics but not in I max , the maximal current ﬂowing through the receptor channel [141–143].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: In adrenal medulla chromafﬁn cells the tyrosine kinases c-SRC and FYN associate with the α3β4 receptor and are involved in the cholinergic stimulation of catecholamine secretion [141,144,145].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: In adrenal medulla chromafﬁn cells the tyrosine kinases c-SRC and FYN associate with the α3β4 receptor and are involved in the cholinergic stimulation of catecholamine secretion [141,144,145].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Speciﬁcally, it has been shown that upon stimulation, α7 AChR activates PI3K via direct association with non-receptor type tyrosine kinase FYN and Janus-activated kinase 2 (JAK2), promoting the survival of neuronal cells (Fig. 3).

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Recent studies have also demonstrated the importance of the phos- phatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway downstream of AChRs in pro- tecting neurons from death and up-regulating these receptors [148].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Recent studies have also demonstrated the importance of the phos- phatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway downstream of AChRs in pro- tecting neurons from death and up-regulating these receptors [148].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Speciﬁcally, it has been shown that upon stimulation, α7 AChR activates PI3K via direct association with non-receptor type tyrosine kinase FYN and Janus-activated kinase 2 (JAK2), promoting the survival of neuronal cells (Fig. 3).

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Speciﬁcally, it has been shown that upon stimulation, α7 AChR activates PI3K via direct association with non-receptor type tyrosine kinase FYN and Janus-activated kinase 2 (JAK2), promoting the survival of neuronal cells (Fig. 3).

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Tyrosine phosphorylation of α7 AChR was found to negatively regulate receptor activity in neuroblastoma cells, hippo- campal CA1 interneurons, and supraoptic magnocellular neurons, whereas de-phosphorylation of α7 AChR was found to potentiate ACh-evoked currents in these cells.

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: BDNF regulates development of neuronal structures both in the pe- ripheral and central nervous systems [150–155].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: BDNF regulates development of neuronal structures both in the pe- ripheral and central nervous systems [150–155].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: It has acute effects on the synapse, serving as an activity-dependent regulator of synaptic plas- ticity and participating in rapid synaptic transmission [150,151,156–159], in the maturation of GABAergic signaling and in the stabilization of newly formed synapses [151,160–163].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: It has acute effects on the synapse, serving as an activity-dependent regulator of synaptic plas- ticity and participating in rapid synaptic transmission [150,151,156–159], in the maturation of GABAergic signaling and in the stabilization of newly formed synapses [151,160–163].

links.evidence: BDNF can also inﬂuence the level of α7 AChRs subunits (Fig. 4) in the hippocampus and other brain regions [160,164,165].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Recent studies using dissociated rat hippocampal neurons in culture demonstrated that BDNF increases both surface and internal α7 AChRs pools.

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Recent studies using dissociated rat hippocampal neurons in culture demonstrated that BDNF increases both surface and internal α7 AChRs pools.

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Furthermore, nicotinic stimulation rapidly induced SNARE-dependent vesicular endocytosis accompanied by receptor internalization [166]. However, the number of surface α7 AChRs was not modiﬁed since a SNARE-dependent pro- cess also recruited receptors to the cell surface from internal pools (Fig. 5).

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: A recent study showed that mutation of amino acids from this region (leucines 335, 336 or 343) to alanine reduced cell-surface expression of α7 AChRs [173].

links.evidence: One of the salient events at early stages of this disease (usually pre- clinical) is the impairment in hippocampus-based episodic memory which can be improved by enhancement of cholinergic transmission [191].

citation.name: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012 Mar;1818(3):718-29. doi: 10.1016/j.bbamem.2011.10.012. Epub 2011 Oct 22.

links.evidence: Another important event that associates well with the Alzheimer disease pathology is the aggregation of the β-amyloid peptide [53]. This peptide interacts with α7 AChRs and has been reported to affect the nor- mal functioning of the latter, causing reduced neuronal survival [146,192–194].
